title: One Day at a Time
body: Recovery happens one day at a time. We don't worry about staying sober forever—just for today. Tomorrow will take care of itself.
reflection: Can you stay sober just for today?

title: One Day at a Time
body: Today is all we have. We can't change yesterday, and tomorrow hasn't arrived yet. Can you stay sober just for today?
reflection: What does 'just for today' mean to you?

title: One Day at a Time
body: The weight of 'forever sober' is crushing. But 24 hours? That's doable. Focus on today.
reflection: How does breaking recovery into 24-hour chunks help?

title: One Day at a Time
body: Each morning, we wake up and commit to one thing: staying sober today. That's it. That's enough.
reflection: What happens when you focus only on today?

title: First Things First
body: Recovery must come first. Before work, before family drama, before anything—put your sobriety first today.
reflection: What needs to come first in your life today?

title: First Things First
body: What's the most important thing? Staying sober. Everything else depends on that foundation.
reflection: Are you putting recovery first, or making excuses?

title: First Things First
body: First things first means recovery isn't just important—it's urgent. Make it priority one.
reflection: What happens if you don't prioritize sobriety?

title: First Things First
body: Your sobriety is the foundation everything else is built on. Protect it first.
reflection: What does 'first things first' look like for you today?

title: Easy Does It
body: Recovery isn't a race. Easy does it. Take things slow, one step at a time.
reflection: Where are you rushing that you should slow down?

title: Easy Does It
body: You don't have to fix everything today. Easy does it. Slow progress is still progress.
reflection: What does 'easy does it' mean in your recovery today?

title: Easy Does It
body: When you feel overwhelmed, remember: easy does it. Breathe. Slow down. One thing at a time.
reflection: Are you being patient with yourself?

title: Easy Does It
body: Rushing recovery leads to burnout. Easy does it means steady, sustainable growth.
reflection: What happens when you try to force things?

title: Progress Not Perfection
body: You don't have to be perfect to recover. Progress, not perfection. Every small step counts.
reflection: Where are you demanding perfection instead of celebrating progress?

title: Progress Not Perfection
body: Perfection is impossible. Progress is inevitable if you keep showing up. That's all that matters.
reflection: What progress have you made this week?

title: Progress Not Perfection
body: Recovery is messy. You'll make mistakes. Progress, not perfection. Keep moving forward.
reflection: How does perfectionism hurt your recovery?

title: Progress Not Perfection
body: Stop waiting to be perfect. Progress is the goal. Are you better than yesterday? That's enough.
reflection: What small step can you take today?

title: Keep It Simple
body: Recovery doesn't need to be complicated. Keep it simple: don't use, go to meetings, ask for help.
reflection: What are you overcomplicating in your recovery?

title: Keep It Simple
body: When recovery feels overwhelming, simplify. What's the one thing you need to do today? Do that.
reflection: What simple action can you take today?

title: Keep It Simple
body: We love to overcomplicate things. Keep it simple. The basics work: meetings, connections, honesty.
reflection: Are you following the basics, or chasing complicated solutions?

title: Keep It Simple
body: Simple doesn't mean easy. But it does mean clear. Keep it simple: stay sober today.
reflection: What does 'keep it simple' mean to you?

title: Let Go and Let God
body: You can't control everything. Let go and let God. Surrender what you can't change.
reflection: What are you trying to control that you need to let go of?

title: Let Go and Let God
body: Holding on tight doesn't help. Let go and let God. Trust the process, trust your Higher Power.
reflection: How does surrendering help your recovery?

title: Let Go and Let God
body: What are you clutching that you need to release? Let go and let God. Surrender brings peace.
reflection: What does 'let God' mean to you?

title: Let Go and Let God
body: Control is an illusion. Let go and let God. Freedom comes through surrender.
reflection: Where are you holding on too tight?

title: This Too Shall Pass
body: This feeling is temporary. This too shall pass. Don't make a permanent decision based on a temporary feeling.
reflection: What difficult feeling are you experiencing that will pass?

title: This Too Shall Pass
body: Cravings pass. Bad days pass. Grief passes. This too shall pass. Ride it out without using.
reflection: Have you seen hard times pass before?

title: This Too Shall Pass
body: Whatever you're feeling right now—it won't last forever. This too shall pass. Stay sober through it.
reflection: How can you ride out this moment without using?

title: This Too Shall Pass
body: Recovery teaches us that nothing lasts forever—not the good, not the bad. This too shall pass.
reflection: What helps you remember that this too shall pass?

title: Live and Let Live
body: You can't control other people. Live and let live. Focus on your own recovery, let others do theirs.
reflection: Who are you trying to control instead of focusing on yourself?

title: Live and Let Live
body: Stop trying to fix everyone else. Live and let live. Your job is your sobriety, not managing theirs.
reflection: What does 'live and let live' mean in your relationships?

title: Live and Let Live
body: Acceptance means live and let live. You do you. Let them do them. Focus on what's in your control.
reflection: How does focusing on others hurt your recovery?

title: Live and Let Live
body: Recovery is personal. Live and let live. What works for you might not work for them—and that's okay.
reflection: Where can you practice acceptance today?

title: Just for Today
body: Just for today, I will stay sober. That's all I need to commit to. Just today.
reflection: Can you commit to staying sober just for today?

title: Just for Today
body: Not forever. Not even tomorrow. Just for today. Can you do that? Just today?
reflection: What makes 'just for today' easier than 'forever'?

title: Just for Today
body: The future is overwhelming. Just for today, focus on staying sober. Tomorrow can wait.
reflection: What do you need to focus on just for today?

title: Just for Today
body: Just for today, recovery is possible. Just for today, you can do this.
reflection: How does this slogan help when you're overwhelmed?

title: Nothing Changes If Nothing Changes
body: Hoping things get better isn't enough. Nothing changes if nothing changes. What action will you take today?
reflection: What needs to change in your life?

title: Nothing Changes If Nothing Changes
body: You can't keep doing the same things and expect different results. Nothing changes if nothing changes.
reflection: What action can you take today to create change?

title: Nothing Changes If Nothing Changes
body: Recovery requires change—in habits, in thinking, in actions. Nothing changes if nothing changes.
reflection: Where are you stuck in old patterns?

title: Nothing Changes If Nothing Changes
body: Waiting for life to improve without changing yourself? Nothing changes if nothing changes. Take action.
reflection: What's one small change you can make right now?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: Recovery works if you work it. Keep coming back. Don't quit before the miracle.
reflection: What makes you want to give up?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: Even if you don't feel like it—keep coming back. Meetings work if you show up.
reflection: How has showing up helped your recovery?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: You belong here. Keep coming back. The program works when you stick with it.
reflection: What keeps you coming back?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: Relapse happens. Shame happens. Keep coming back anyway. The door is always open.
reflection: Who needs to hear 'keep coming back' today?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: Want to stay sober? Go to meetings. Meeting makers make it. Show up, connect, heal.
reflection: How many meetings have you attended this week?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: Meetings aren't optional—they're essential. Meeting makers make it. How many have you been to this week?
reflection: What happens when you skip meetings?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: You can't stay sober alone. Meeting makers make it. Connection is medicine.
reflection: How do meetings support your recovery?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: Skipping meetings? People who don't go don't hear what happens to people who don't go. Meeting makers make it.
reflection: Who can you meet with this week?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: Don't let personality clashes derail your recovery. Principles before personalities. Focus on the program.
reflection: Are you letting personalities distract you from principles?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: You won't like everyone in recovery. That's okay. Principles before personalities. Take what helps, leave the rest.
reflection: What recovery principle do you need to focus on today?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: Someone annoys you at a meeting? Principles before personalities. You're here for sobriety, not friendships.
reflection: How can you practice tolerance?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: The principles of recovery matter more than who delivers them. Principles before personalities.
reflection: Where are you putting personalities before principles?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: One drink leads to chaos. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough. Don't start.
reflection: Do you still believe you can moderate?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: You can't have just one. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough. Stay sober.
reflection: What happens when you take the first drink?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: The first drink does the damage. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough. Remember that.
reflection: How does this slogan protect you?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: Addiction doesn't do moderation. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough.
reflection: Are you romanticizing 'just one'?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: Choose your crew carefully. Stick with the winners. Surround yourself with sober success.
reflection: Who are the 'winners' in your recovery circle?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: Hanging out with people who are slipping? Stick with the winners. Find people who are thriving.
reflection: Are you surrounding yourself with healthy recovery?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: You become who you spend time with. Stick with the winners. Choose your recovery circle wisely.
reflection: What makes someone a 'winner' in recovery?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: Winners aren't perfect—they're committed. Stick with the winners. Learn from people who are doing it right.
reflection: Who should you spend more time with?

title: One Day at a Time
body: Recovery happens one day at a time. We don't worry about staying sober forever—just for today. Tomorrow will take care of itself.
reflection: Can you stay sober just for today?

body: The principles of recovery matter more than who delivers them. Principles before personalities.
reflection: Where are you putting personalities before principles?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: One drink leads to chaos. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough. Don't start.
reflection: Do you still believe you can moderate?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: You can't have just one. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough. Stay sober.
reflection: What happens when you take the first drink?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: The first drink does the damage. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough. Remember that.
reflection: How does this slogan protect you?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: Addiction doesn't do moderation. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough.
reflection: Are you romanticizing 'just one'?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: Choose your crew carefully. Stick with the winners. Surround yourself with sober success.
reflection: Who are the 'winners' in your recovery circle?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: Hanging out with people who are slipping? Stick with the winners. Find people who are thriving.
reflection: Are you surrounding yourself with healthy recovery?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: You become who you spend time with. Stick with the winners. Choose your recovery circle wisely.
reflection: What makes someone a 'winner' in recovery?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: Winners aren't perfect—they're committed. Stick with the winners. Learn from people who are doing it right.
reflection: Who should you spend more time with?

title: One Day at a Time
body: Recovery happens one day at a time. We don't worry about staying sober forever—just for today. Tomorrow will take care of itself.
reflection: Can you stay sober just for today?

title: One Day at a Time
body: Today is all we have. We can't change yesterday, and tomorrow hasn't arrived yet. Can you stay sober just for today?
reflection: What does 'just for today' mean to you?

title: One Day at a Time
body: The weight of 'forever sober' is crushing. But 24 hours? That's doable. Focus on today.
reflection: How does breaking recovery into 24-hour chunks help?

title: One Day at a Time
body: Each morning, we wake up and commit to one thing: staying sober today. That's it. That's enough.
reflection: What happens when you focus only on today?

title: First Things First
body: Recovery must come first. Before work, before family drama, before anything—put your sobriety first today.
reflection: What needs to come first in your life today?

title: First Things First
body: What's the most important thing? Staying sober. Everything else depends on that foundation.
reflection: Are you putting recovery first, or making excuses?

title: First Things First
body: First things first means recovery isn't just important—it's urgent. Make it priority one.
reflection: What happens if you don't prioritize sobriety?

title: First Things First
body: Your sobriety is the foundation everything else is built on. Protect it first.
reflection: What does 'first things first' look like for you today?

title: Easy Does It
body: Recovery isn't a race. Easy does it. Take things slow, one step at a time.
reflection: Where are you rushing that you should slow down?

title: Easy Does It
body: You don't have to fix everything today. Easy does it. Slow progress is still progress.
reflection: What does 'easy does it' mean in your recovery today?

title: Easy Does It
body: When you feel overwhelmed, remember: easy does it. Breathe. Slow down. One thing at a time.
reflection: Are you being patient with yourself?

title: Easy Does It
body: Rushing recovery leads to burnout. Easy does it means steady, sustainable growth.
reflection: What happens when you try to force things?

title: Progress Not Perfection
body: You don't have to be perfect to recover. Progress, not perfection. Every small step counts.
reflection: Where are you demanding perfection instead of celebrating progress?

title: Progress Not Perfection
body: Perfection is impossible. Progress is inevitable if you keep showing up. That's all that matters.
reflection: What progress have you made this week?

title: Progress Not Perfection
body: Recovery is messy. You'll make mistakes. Progress, not perfection. Keep moving forward.
reflection: How does perfectionism hurt your recovery?

title: Progress Not Perfection
body: Stop waiting to be perfect. Progress is the goal. Are you better than yesterday? That's enough.
reflection: What small step can you take today?

title: Keep It Simple
body: Recovery doesn't need to be complicated. Keep it simple: don't use, go to meetings, ask for help.
reflection: What are you overcomplicating in your recovery?

title: Keep It Simple
body: When recovery feels overwhelming, simplify. What's the one thing you need to do today? Do that.
reflection: What simple action can you take today?

title: Keep It Simple
body: We love to overcomplicate things. Keep it simple. The basics work: meetings, connections, honesty.
reflection: Are you following the basics, or chasing complicated solutions?

title: Keep It Simple
body: Simple doesn't mean easy. But it does mean clear. Keep it simple: stay sober today.
reflection: What does 'keep it simple' mean to you?

title: Let Go and Let God
body: You can't control everything. Let go and let God. Surrender what you can't change.
reflection: What are you trying to control that you need to let go of?

title: Let Go and Let God
body: Holding on tight doesn't help. Let go and let God. Trust the process, trust your Higher Power.
reflection: How does surrendering help your recovery?

title: Let Go and Let God
body: What are you clutching that you need to release? Let go and let God. Surrender brings peace.
reflection: What does 'let God' mean to you?

title: Let Go and Let God
body: Control is an illusion. Let go and let God. Freedom comes through surrender.
reflection: Where are you holding on too tight?

title: This Too Shall Pass
body: This feeling is temporary. This too shall pass. Don't make a permanent decision based on a temporary feeling.
reflection: What difficult feeling are you experiencing that will pass?

title: This Too Shall Pass
body: Cravings pass. Bad days pass. Grief passes. This too shall pass. Ride it out without using.
reflection: Have you seen hard times pass before?

title: This Too Shall Pass
body: Whatever you're feeling right now—it won't last forever. This too shall pass. Stay sober through it.
reflection: How can you ride out this moment without using?

title: This Too Shall Pass
body: Recovery teaches us that nothing lasts forever—not the good, not the bad. This too shall pass.
reflection: What helps you remember that this too shall pass?

title: Live and Let Live
body: You can't control other people. Live and let live. Focus on your own recovery, let others do theirs.
reflection: Who are you trying to control instead of focusing on yourself?

title: Live and Let Live
body: Stop trying to fix everyone else. Live and let live. Your job is your sobriety, not managing theirs.
reflection: What does 'live and let live' mean in your relationships?

title: Live and Let Live
body: Acceptance means live and let live. You do you. Let them do them. Focus on what's in your control.
reflection: How does focusing on others hurt your recovery?

title: Live and Let Live
body: Recovery is personal. Live and let live. What works for you might not work for them—and that's okay.
reflection: Where can you practice acceptance today?

title: Just for Today
body: Just for today, I will stay sober. That's all I need to commit to. Just today.
reflection: Can you commit to staying sober just for today?

title: Just for Today
body: Not forever. Not even tomorrow. Just for today. Can you do that? Just today?
reflection: What makes 'just for today' easier than 'forever'?

title: Just for Today
body: The future is overwhelming. Just for today, focus on staying sober. Tomorrow can wait.
reflection: What do you need to focus on just for today?

title: Just for Today
body: Just for today, recovery is possible. Just for today, you can do this.
reflection: How does this slogan help when you're overwhelmed?

title: Nothing Changes If Nothing Changes
body: Hoping things get better isn't enough. Nothing changes if nothing changes. What action will you take today?
reflection: What needs to change in your life?

title: Nothing Changes If Nothing Changes
body: You can't keep doing the same things and expect different results. Nothing changes if nothing changes.
reflection: What action can you take today to create change?

title: Nothing Changes If Nothing Changes
body: Recovery requires change—in habits, in thinking, in actions. Nothing changes if nothing changes.
reflection: Where are you stuck in old patterns?

title: Nothing Changes If Nothing Changes
body: Waiting for life to improve without changing yourself? Nothing changes if nothing changes. Take action.
reflection: What's one small change you can make right now?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: Recovery works if you work it. Keep coming back. Don't quit before the miracle.
reflection: What makes you want to give up?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: Even if you don't feel like it—keep coming back. Meetings work if you show up.
reflection: How has showing up helped your recovery?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: You belong here. Keep coming back. The program works when you stick with it.
reflection: What keeps you coming back?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: Relapse happens. Shame happens. Keep coming back anyway. The door is always open.
reflection: Who needs to hear 'keep coming back' today?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: Want to stay sober? Go to meetings. Meeting makers make it. Show up, connect, heal.
reflection: How many meetings have you attended this week?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: Meetings aren't optional—they're essential. Meeting makers make it. How many have you been to this week?
reflection: What happens when you skip meetings?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: You can't stay sober alone. Meeting makers make it. Connection is medicine.
reflection: How do meetings support your recovery?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: Skipping meetings? People who don't go don't hear what happens to people who don't go. Meeting makers make it.
reflection: Who can you meet with this week?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: Don't let personality clashes derail your recovery. Principles before personalities. Focus on the program.
reflection: Are you letting personalities distract you from principles?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: You won't like everyone in recovery. That's okay. Principles before personalities. Take what helps, leave the rest.
reflection: What recovery principle do you need to focus on today?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: Someone annoys you at a meeting? Principles before personalities. You're here for sobriety, not friendships.
reflection: How can you practice tolerance?

body: The principles of recovery matter more than who delivers them. Principles before personalities.
reflection: Where are you putting personalities before principles?

reflection: What makes you want to give up?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: Even if you don't feel like it—keep coming back. Meetings work if you show up.
reflection: How has showing up helped your recovery?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: You belong here. Keep coming back. The program works when you stick with it.
reflection: What keeps you coming back?

title: Keep Coming Back
body: Relapse happens. Shame happens. Keep coming back anyway. The door is always open.
reflection: Who needs to hear 'keep coming back' today?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: Want to stay sober? Go to meetings. Meeting makers make it. Show up, connect, heal.
reflection: How many meetings have you attended this week?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: Meetings aren't optional—they're essential. Meeting makers make it. How many have you been to this week?
reflection: What happens when you skip meetings?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: You can't stay sober alone. Meeting makers make it. Connection is medicine.
reflection: How do meetings support your recovery?

title: Meeting Makers Make It
body: Skipping meetings? People who don't go don't hear what happens to people who don't go. Meeting makers make it.
reflection: Who can you meet with this week?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: Don't let personality clashes derail your recovery. Principles before personalities. Focus on the program.
reflection: Are you letting personalities distract you from principles?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: You won't like everyone in recovery. That's okay. Principles before personalities. Take what helps, leave the rest.
reflection: What recovery principle do you need to focus on today?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: Someone annoys you at a meeting? Principles before personalities. You're here for sobriety, not friendships.
reflection: How can you practice tolerance?

title: Principles Before Personalities
body: The principles of recovery matter more than who delivers them. Principles before personalities.
reflection: Where are you putting personalities before principles?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: One drink leads to chaos. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough. Don't start.
reflection: Do you still believe you can moderate?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: You can't have just one. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough. Stay sober.
reflection: What happens when you take the first drink?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: The first drink does the damage. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough. Remember that.
reflection: How does this slogan protect you?

title: One Drink Is Too Many, A Thousand Not Enough
body: Addiction doesn't do moderation. One drink is too many, a thousand not enough.
reflection: Are you romanticizing 'just one'?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: Choose your crew carefully. Stick with the winners. Surround yourself with sober success.
reflection: Who are the 'winners' in your recovery circle?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: Hanging out with people who are slipping? Stick with the winners. Find people who are thriving.
reflection: Are you surrounding yourself with healthy recovery?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: You become who you spend time with. Stick with the winners. Choose your recovery circle wisely.
reflection: What makes someone a 'winner' in recovery?

title: Stick With the Winners
body: Winners aren't perfect—they're committed. Stick with the winners. Learn from people who are doing it right.
reflection: Who should you spend more time with?

title: One Day at a Time
body: Recovery happens one day at a time. We don't worry about staying sober forever—just for today. Tomorrow will take care of itself.
reflection: Can you stay sober just for today?

title: One Day at a Time
body: Today is all we have. We can't change yesterday, and tomorrow hasn't arrived yet. Can you stay sober just for today?
reflection: What does 'just for today' mean to you?

title: One Day at a Time
body: The weight of 'forever sober' is crushing. But 24 hours? That's doable. Focus on today.
reflection: How does breaking recovery into 24-hour chunks help?

title: One Day at a Time
body: Each morning, we wake up and commit to one thing: staying sober today. That's it. That's enough.
reflection: What happens when you focus only on today?

title: First Things First
body: Recovery must come first. Before work, before family drama, before anything—put your sobriety first today.
reflection: What needs to come first in your life today?
